awd_titl_txt: Poisson Geometry, Quantum Moduli, and Geometric Dualities
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a research in algebraic geometry. The field of algebraic geometry studies geometric models by distilling and encoding their essential complexity in polynomial equations. The project integrates ideas from quantum physics and the physical study of symmetries of the fundamental laws of nature to extract new and unexpected information about the geometry of spaces. The project will focus on unravelling the hidden structure of multi-dimensional geometric models of quantum fields and to capture this structure in a cascade of polynomial invariants. These invariants will give a new mathematical tool for understanding and proving various empirically observed physics dualities which are expected to identify a priori unrelated quantum theories. The project aims to unify the analytic and geometric properties of parameter spaces of representations in arbitrary dimension and sets the stage for understanding the basic structure of moduli problems in a way suitable for pragmatic use in a broad spectrum of applications. The proposed work will be immediately relevant to deep questions in symplectic geometry, geometric representation theory, string theory and quantum field theory.


Three directions will be studied. The first is to investigate how the Hodge theory of varieties with potentials and the associated perverse and weight filtrations are exchanged by T-duality. In the second project a new method will be developed for constructing moduli of irregular connections on non-compact algebraic manifolds, for building explicit symplectic foliations, and for computing their leaves. This will involve a new de Rham theory of formal boundaries of varieties, and a new construction of sheaf theoretic invariants from the formal geometry. The final project will build  a spectral coverformalism for constructing Hecke eigensheaves on moduli of bundles related to intersections of quadrics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Using techniques from derived algebraic geometry, the PI developed a
novel non-commutative geometry toolbox to construct new invariants and
higher symmetries of moduli spaces in quantum field theory, new
representations of algebraic groups, and to study classical and
derived integrable systems. The toolbox allows for both local and
global analysis and creates an explicit bridge between local and
global quantization schemes.



Three projects were completed.  In the first project the PI studied
and classified the secondary topological filtrations on the
non-commutative Hodge structures and exponential motives associated
with varieties with potentials and studied how they change under
mirror symmetry and non-commutative descent in the cases of toric Fano
varieties, and for tame Poisson compactifications of holomorphic
symplectic manifolds. The duality and gluing results were utilized to
construct filtrations and decomposition of universes in quantum field
theory with respect to the action of higher group and higher form
symmetries.  In the second project the PI introduced a new universal
method for constructing symplectic and Poisson structures on moduli of
tame flat bundles and local systems on smooth quasi-projective
varieties of arbitrary dimension. The method relies on an original
categorical derived geometry technique which was specifically
developed for the project. The method was applied by the PI to
computations of representation theoretic obstructions to non-abelian
Lefschetz dualities, to the construction of quantum invariants in low
dimensional topology, and to the study of perturbative quantization
and symmetries in higher dimensional field theory. Several graduate
students trained and supported within the project used the novel
methodology to solve fundamental open problems in the field, including
a proof of the duality between semi-polarized meromorphic Hitchin and
Calabi-Yau integrable systems, a spectral characterization of
stability of tame extended flat triples on curves, a proof of a strong
descent property of the mirror perverse-weight correspondence, a
construction of multi-potential mirrors of semi-stable degenerations
of Calabi-Yau manifolds, and the development of a new theory of
parabolic multiplicative affine Springer fibers.  In the third project
the PI extended the ramified tame non-abelian Hodge theory to
construct twistor D-modules which are Hecke eigensheaves, and to
resolve some outstanding conjectures in geometric representation
theory, and prove a strong compatibility between geometric Fourier and
Radon transforms.

The completion of these projects is essential for understanding
complicated enhancements of structures in algebraic geometry,
symplectic topology, and theoretical and mathematical physics. The
solutions obtained by the PI set the stage for understanding the local
and global complexity of common zeroes of polynomial equations in a
way suitable for pragmatic use in a broad spectrum of
applications. Aside from the natural applications to algebraic
geometry and topology, the carried out work tackled open problems in
category theory, geometric representation theory, the theory of
integrable systems, string theory, quantum field theory, and gauge
theory.

 

While completing this research program the PI organized a concentrated
effort on enhancing and building a new geometric arsenal of techniques
applicable to the theory of algebraic cycles, symplectic topology, and
high energy physics. This was achieved by training four postdoctoral
researchers, six Ph.D. and two M.Sc students in mathematics and
physics, and by a curriculum development of courses on higher quantum
symmetries, singular non-abelian Hodge theory, 3d mirror symmetry, and
generalized geometry.  The work was disseminated through talks at
multidisciplinary conferences, courses at graduate schools, research
seminars, publications in peer reviewed scientific journals, and a
peer reviewed research monograph.
